results.title: Glassmakers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Is Britain”.
A survey of the wide range of glass products manufactured by British craftsmen. Includes manufacture of plate glass and installation of a large sheet in one of the Festival of Britain buildings; making of stained glass windows; manufacture of optical glass and lenses; prisms and lanterns for lighthouses; production of electric light globes; glass blowing and making of nahd0made cut glass.

results.title: The Man of fashion
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Is Britain”.
Discusses, in humorous fashion, the evolution of men’s clothes, showing how details of dress have evolved over the years. The role of fashion is portrayed in the work of a master tailor, fitting an Englishman in the latest style. From this new style a new trend may emerge in the fashionable West End of London and spread to tailoring establishments throughout the country.

results.title: Health
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Is Britain”.
Cinemagazine newsreel items including: 1. Research on the common cold at Havard Hospital, Salisbury, using human beings for test purposes. 2. The manufacture of hypodermic needles and syringes. 3. Limbless people learning to use aritifical legs and arms at a National Health Service Clinic.

results.title: Auto suggestion
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Is Britain”.
Illustrates technical advances in the British motor-car industry showing the fine quality and workmanship of products manufactured. Cars shown include the following: Daimler Straight Eight, Rolls-Royce Silver Wraith, Morris Minor, Vauxhall Wyvern, Austin A40, Hillman Minx, Ford Prefect, Triumph Mayflower, Jaguar XK120 amd Mark VII Saloon, Ford Consul, Triumph Roadster, production version of the 2.1/2 litre Aston Marton, Bristol 401, and the experimental Rover Gas Turbine prototype.

results.title: Golden Gate
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Is America”.
San Francisco is the subject of this United States Travel Service program, from the series, “This Is America”. It is a colourful and breezy look at the Californian city which attracts so many tourists annually. Highlights include Fisherman’s Wharf, the Golden Gate Bridge, Chinatown and Alcatraz

results.title: Mona Hatoum [Widescreen]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “TheEYE”.
Part of a series of interview-based profiles of contemporary visual artists in Britain. The artist Mona Hatoum came to London from Lebanon in 1975. Working initially with performance and video, and in the 1990s with sculpture and installations, she has exhibited widely around the world. In the summer of 2000, Mona Hatoum presented three major new works which marked the inauguration of Tate Britain, London. These works, exhibited under the title ‘The Entire World as a Foreign Land’, developed Hatoum’s interest in the relationship between individual identity and the notion of a broader cultural and geographic identity, or sense of ‘belonging’. In this interview, illustrated with these works and with other key installations, Hatoum explores the diverse sources of her work and her engagement with a wide range of often surprising materials. The artist talks vividly about the centrality of the body to her installations, and the ways in which her work employs changes of scale, intimations of restriction and constraint, and contradictory ideas of attraction and repulsion.

results.title: Dalziel and Scullion [Widescreen]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “TheEYE”.
Part of a series of interview-based profiles of contemporary visual artists in Britain. Artists Matthew Dalziel and Louise Scullion have worked together since 1993, based in the remote north east of Scotland. Using photography, video, sculpture, sound and installation, they have created a collection of work that is recognised for its distinctive vision and sensitivity to its context and the environment. The point at which nature and culture intersect is a continuing theme throughout their work. Well known for their site-specific works, which include important public commissions, their art reflects on the primary themes of landscape, evolution, religion and time, and represents a rediscovery of landscape as a means of reflecting on fundamental ideas about the world we live in today. In this profile, Dalziel and Scullion discuss their continuing fascination with timescales and how their work attempts to reflect on the vast gap that exists between the limits of human history and the incomprehensible span of geological processes and creation.

results.title: Julian Opie [Widescreen]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “TheEYE”.
Part of a series of interview-based profiles of contemporary visual artists in Britain - this episode focuses on Julian Opie. Opie is a renowned artist who works across a range of media and styles. An installation artist, sculptor, painter and printmaker, Opie creates bold portraits, subtle landscapes, unconventional wallpaper, playful sculptures of animals, buildings and cars, and computer films presenting simplified and iconic versions of the contemporary environment. He has embraced computer art, clearly delighted with the possibilities that it affords him, allowing work to be created in non-traditional ways. Inspired by toys, architectural models, and all manner of modern signage, Opie engages with the themes of realism and memory, placing recognisably familiar objects into abstract circumstances. Opie also designed the cover art for the album “Best of Blur”, creating four portraits of the band members. These works now hang in the National Portrait Gallery. In interview Opie explains the motivations behind his work, his shifts in focus and the desire to explore new means of expression.
